SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the usefulness of brain MRI as compared to orbital MRI in the assessment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH)
METHODS: The study was carried out at King Abdul-Aziz University Hospital, Jeddah, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia between January 2002 and December 2003
An MRI of the head and orbits was performed for 42 patients with the clinical diagnosis of IIH, and 15 normal volunteers
All cases of secondary increased intracranial pressure were eliminated
The images were evaluated for the presence of empty sella, parenchymal abnormalities, ventricular and sulcal size changes, optic disc elevation, and optic nerve sheath distention
RESULTS: The MRI of the head revealed empty sella in 29 patients and in one normal volunteer
Brain MRI did not reveal any parenchymal, ventricular or cisternal abnormalities in either group
Orbital MRI revealed optic nerve sheath distension and optic disc elevation in 36 patients, and were normal in all volunteers
CONCLUSION: Brain MRI has limited value in the evaluation of IIH
Orbital MRI is the recommended imaging modality for this entity
